dialogues.text: The hallway is a mess. A window opening onto a light well open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the apartment is suddenly broken open. A plai clothes detective, two uniformed police officers and seve firemen - also in uniform - enter and look around. They a wear gloves and masks that cover their mouths and noses. Behind them, the superintendent and his wife also push th way in. They're both holding their noses. In his free han the superintendent holds a pile of mail and promotional flyers. Behind him, comes a female neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the superintendent and the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait Outside please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He signals to a police officer who herds the curious onlookers back out through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the superintendent, pointing to a pile of mail) What's the date of the last letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 16th from what I can see... Wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plain-clothes detective has tried in vain to open the door on the left. It has been sealed up with adhesive tap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the fire officer) Can you try?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While the firemen go to work on the door, the plain-cloth detective goes into the adjoining dining room. He opens t windows quickly and turns to go into the room to the left the double doors. They are locked and the gaps are also t up. He turns to the right and goes into the living room, where he also opens up the windows...

dialogues.speaker: FIREMAN, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: The door is open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and comes back into the hallway, passing by the waitin firemen. Once again, we hear snatches of dialogue between police officer and the janitor. 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...no as far as I know. During the whole time, they had a nurse, but it's been a while since I last saw her. My wife has been...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plain-clothes detective enters the bedroom which is n accessible. Its windows are open and the draft makes the curtains billow into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the firemen who are now curious enough to come and stand by the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you open the windows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The firemen shake their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PLAIN-CLOTHES DETECTIVE turns toward the big double b placed against the back wall of the bedroom. On the right hand bed, there's only the bare mattress. On the left-han bed lies the partly decomposed body of an old woman. Wher once there were eyes, now there are only gaping holes. Th corpse has been neatly dressed and is adorned with flower that have already dried out a little. On her chest is a crucifix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCENE 2 - White letters on a black background: THE CREDIT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we see is the audience pouring into the hall. GEORGES ANNE, both are around eighty, are part of this crowd. The to their seats in one of the rows near the front. Once everybody is seated, we hear the usual ANNOUNCEMENT askin people to turn off their mobile phones. Some people, caug with their phones switched on, hasten to comply. Then the lights go out. APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off-screen, we hear the soloist make his entrance. THROAT ARE CLEARED here and there. Finally, the MUSIC begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music from Scene 3 continues. The soloist is surround by admirers who congratulate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Georges and Anne push their way into the room. (If th soloist is female, they will be carrying flowers, like mo of the others). 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the soloist notices their presence, he leaves his gr of fans, heads towards them and greets them very warmly, visibly glad to see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continuation of the MUSIC from Scene 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges and Anne are seated side by side in the half empt bus. Anne talks enthusiastically, Georges says something time to time, and smiles now and then. They are both rela and happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the apartment is unlocked and opened from the outside. THE MUSIC ENDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges comes in, turns on the light. He and Anne observe open door. Around the lock, one can see the traces of an attempted forced entry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges bends down and runs his fingers over the deep grooves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They used a screwdriver or something like that...it doesn't look very professional...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who would do something like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No idea. Why do people break in? Because they want to steal something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs briefly out loud) Hey, why not? If I thought about it, I could come up with at least three or four people we know who've been burgled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After having examined the outside of the second leaf of t double door, he comes in, closing the door behind him. 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it? Can't we call the superintendent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do that tomorrow morning. Anyway, they didn't see anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unbuttons his overcoat and heads toward the large clos in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let it spoil your good mood now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, give me your coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes toward him, he takes her coat off and hangs it w his in the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine if we were here, in our beds, and someone broke in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I imagine that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's terrible! I think I'd die of fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So would I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He undoes his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we have a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still fancy a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts away his shoes with the others and slips on his slippers. Anne has gone into the bathroom. 5.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Go ahead then. Mathilde told me that in her building, the attic apartment was burgled from the loft. They just knocked a hole in the wall, cut out all of the valuable pictures from their frames and disappeared without a trace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must have been professionals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he passes in front of the bathroom, he stops and appea to be looking at Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I tell you, you looked good tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's got into you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a gentle LAUGH, Georges disappears into the kitchen, where he turns on the lights. We hear him FIDDLING AROUND apparently getting a glass and some wine. After a short

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weren't those semiquavers in the presto incredible? What staccato! Don't you agree?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: You're proud of him, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges wakes up. He looks with amazement beside him, the raises his eyes. Anne is sitting upright, her back agains the headboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a while, the RINGING of a kitchen egg-timer leads u the next scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The egg timer in the kitchen RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is seated in front of the window, at a table whic half set for breakfast. He has mobile phone raised to his and a phone book opened in front of him. Anne is getting from the table. She goes toward the stove, turns off the takes the egg out of the pan with a spoon and runs it und cold water. Like Georges, she is still in her robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone) What about next week? No but still, it would make sense to get it done soon. It might give people silly ideas. And anyway, it's too ugly to look at... Wednesday? What time? OK... Will you bring the paint with you too, to paint over it? But at least some primer...Yes, OK. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can depend on that guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who comes back to the table with the egg) I hope so. The last time, he kept us waiting for ages, if you remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs while acquiescing) Yes, that's true. (Reacting when she places the egg in his egg cup) Thanks. If I call a regular professional, we'll still be waiting two months time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more to herself) Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has sat down. Looks straight ahead. He cracks open hi egg, puts salt on it, eats. 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Frodons waited three days when their toilet was blocked. Not exactly pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eats. Wants to put on more salt, but the saltcellar is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The saltcellar is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up for an instant, as if he expected her to deal with it. As she doesn't react, he realizes the inappropriateness of such an expectation, gets up himself heads for the kitchen cupboards and fills the salt cellar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if he's going to bring us the CD. Maybe he won't come at all. In any case, he didn't mention it. I'd like to buy it. It was really good and I don't want to wait long for it. We could go to Virgin this afternoon and buy it. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He comes back to the table and sits down again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm? Anne? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him and doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves his hand in front of her eyes and laughs nervous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helllloooo!!! Cuckoo!!! I'm here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues to look at him without reacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (serious now) Anne! What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits, looks at her. No reaction. He stands up slightl leans over the table to sit beside her. Tries to make her turn toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, what's the matter? 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He manages to get her torso to turn halfway toward him, b her eyes look through him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne...what's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her face in both hands and turns toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares into the void. He drops his hands. Then sits beside her, for quite awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally he gets up, heads for the sink, turns on the tap, wets a tea towel, wrings it out a little, comes back and places it on Anne's face. Waits for a reaction that doesn come. Then he pulls up her hair in the nape of her neck a applies the cloth there. Then sits down and looks at her imploringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (close to tears) Anne...Darling...please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again they both remain seated. In the background, we hear the GUSHING of the tap that in his panic he has forgotten to turn it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making a sudden decision, he gets up, rapidly crossing th hallway, he goes into the bedroom where he starts to dres agitatedly, which takes him quite a lot of time. Suddenly the GUSHING of the tap stops, which had accompanied us as as the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George doesn't notice it immediately, then he stops short

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally he returns, half dressed, into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is seated in the same place and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns toward the breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You left the water running. 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (both aghast and furious) Hey, what's going on? Are you completely crazy? Is this supposed to be a joke, or what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him with amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a joke? Is this meant to be a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What joke? I don't get it! Why are you talking to me like that? What's got into you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges comes from the door to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne! Please! Stop this game. It's not funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What game, for Christ's sake? What on earth's the matter?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is about to answer in a similarly irritated tone, but gradually begins to suspect that he could be mistaken tries to calm down, takes his chair that has remained bes Anne, sits down and looks at his wife. She doesn't know h to react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Why didn't you react?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what? To me, to everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just now. A moment ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell me what's wrong. What am I supposed to have done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges first looks away reluctantly, then looks at Anne. doesn't want to believe that its serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say. Do you really not know what just happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what DID happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost reluctantly bowing his head as he speaks) You were sitting there, staring at me. You didn't answer me when I asked you what the matter was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the wet tea towel from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put this tea towel on your face, and you didn't react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne looks at the towel, then at Georges, and shakes her head, perturbed that she can't understand. Georges looks her. He sees the damp marks on the collar of her robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... There's still dampness on your collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne follows his gesture, tugs on her collar and sees the damp marks. She slowly grasps that something is awry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When... When was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just now, a few minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no "So". I went into the bedroom to get dressed. I wanted to get help. 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and then you turned off the tap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Because you left it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think it's best if I call Dr. Bertier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? What can he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Examine you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. There's nothing wrong with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, please!! That's absurd. We can't pretend that nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what DID happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here. I'm having my breakfast, and you're telling me things happened that I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you explain how the tea towel got there? 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who turned on the tap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you remember that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more and more desperate, close to tears) No I can't! Do you want to torture me? Leave me in peace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think it would be better to fetch Dr. Bertier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes her cup of tea, as if to show how well she is, drinks it up. When she wants to re-fill her cup, she completely misses her aim. She notices it, puts down her and bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see wide shots of the apartment. The hallway. The bedr The living room. The dining room. The kitchen. Nobody in sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EVA, around 50, has come to pay a visit. Anne isn't there

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how he is. Once he's got something into his head, he has to go through with it. In the end, everybody was delighted. And besides, it didn't hurt our financial situation. We're playing until the 28th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we have 10 days to rest, then we go to Stockholm for four days, and then to Kumo in Finland. Heaven knows where that is. At the North Pole. But Geoff's already been there few times, and he loves it. We're playing the "Dowland Transcriptions" there and then we're back in London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz is at boarding school and John is living his own life. He's twenty- six years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a student. We rarely see him. He's got his own ideas. Life Geoff. They don't really get along. Geoff wants to advise him on everything, and John doesn't like that at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so. He's less impulsive. Very industrious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds rather derogatory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!! He's not like Geoff. Quiet, but stubborn. I think he'll do all right. At the last Conservatory concert, he played the solo part in the Haydn Concerto. It was very good. Geoff was there and congratulated him at the end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you both make up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a little laugh) My God, you know him, don't you? Over the winter, he suddenly discovered his passion for a viola player who'd been in our ensemble for years. What can I tell you? It was a huge drama, and the poor little darling wound up trying to commit suicide. That scared him and he came back to me in full remorse. I've got used to it now. What's a bit embarrassing is that the ensemble, you can't keep any secrets from anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's aphasia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges gestures that it's too complicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I say? The carotid artery was blocked. They did an ultrasound scan, two in fact, and they said they had to operate on her. She was scared. She was confused and scared. You know she has always been afraid of doctors. They said the risk was very low and that if they didn't operate, she'd be certain to have a serious stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do they say now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just that it didn't go well. It's one of the 5% that go wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He yawns. 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pretty upsetting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Usually at this time, I take a nap. My blood sugar is somewhere down in my socks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. It was nice of you to come despite all of your stress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really. There's nothing you can do. We'll see how things go when she's back here in the apartment. We'll manage. Maybe I'll get a caretaker in, or maybe I'll manage on my own. We'll see. We've been through quite a lot in our time, your mother and I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this is still a bit new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a little laugh) It's funny. I don't know if I should say it. Maybe it'll embarrass you. But when I came here a short while ago, I suddenly remembered how I always used to listen to the two of you making love when I was little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me, at the time, it was reassuring. It gave me a feeling that you loved each other, and that we'd always be together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A carpenter and his assistant are raising the base of the double bed. Georges watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door of the apartment is opened. Georges comes in. Be him is Anne in a wheelchair, pushed by a paramedic. A sec paramedic (as young as the first) follows with a suitcase a large bag. Behind them, the superintendent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges tries to rid of the three as quickly as possible. stuffs a twenty euro note into the hand of the first paramedic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Thank you very much. It's for both of you. You can just put the things down here. There, beside the window, right. We'll be okay on our own. Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two paramedics exchange a brief glance, say thanks, a leave the apartment, passing the superintendent as they g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the superintendent) Thank you, Mr. Mery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you need anything, just call downstairs. If we can help at all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now everything's fine. I'll let your wife know as soon as we need anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to have you back, Mrs. Laurent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you, Mr. Mery. Thank you. 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The superintendent hesitates another moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... So... Goodbye then, ma'am. Welcome home again. Goodbye, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Mr. Mery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a brief moment of perplexity. Then Georges says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a nervous smile) Where do you want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges pushes her toward the living room door, walks aro the wheelchair, opens the door, comes back behind the wheelchair and pushes Anne into the LIVING ROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorway is narrow. The wheelchair only just passes through it. Georges pushes Anne toward the sofa and the armchairs and then steps in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I make some tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a faint smile) First come sit with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George registers her smile; he knows he's behaving in a clumsy way. He sits down in one of the two arm chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you help me into the chair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges stands back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He extends his hands. She puts on the wheelchair brake, l the footrest with her left foot, raises her right leg fro the footrest with her left hand and then extends her left to Georges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's best if you put my arm around your neck and your right arm around me, that way it'll be easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does as he is told, pulls her up as they hobble togeth the short distance to the second arm chair. Cautiously, h lowers her down and helps her sit herself straight. Becau they are not used to it, the whole process appears awkwar and clumsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles because it seems silly to him to answer "Don't mention it". Then he sits down opposite her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first they are both ill at ease, but then they accept fact that words do not come easily. After a long while, during which we hear the intermittent sound of the TRAFFI below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly almost to himself) I'm glad you're back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a voice just as soft) Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another PAUSE. Then Anne says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please never take me back to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him. He has understood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk right now. And don't give me any lectures. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I say, it's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just don't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He helps her into bed, then throws the blanket over her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you, Darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hesitates. 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to hold my hand all the time now. I can look after myself, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't feel guilty. That would be pointless. And a drag. For me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't feel guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go over there now. I'm not a cripple. You can easily leave me alone for two minutes. I won't collapse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slight smile) OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you buy the new book on Harnoncourt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want it? I'll get it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out of the room to fetch the book. She remains ly there, waiting, and runs her healthy left hand through he hair to make herself look prettier, then smooths out the blanket that has slipped out of place a little. After a while, we hear Georges shouting. 21.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't know where I put it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. It isn't that important.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGES, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. Hold on, maybe it's in the... Just a moment! Viola! Here you are! Nothing like an infallible memory!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles, looks in his direction. He enters with the bo in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd left it over there in the other room, but I'd already put it away. Tidy people just can't help being tidy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the book) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts the book on her stomach. Looks at Georges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now, take care of yourself. And don't wait to see how I hold the book in my hand, OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her for a moment longer, then leaves the bedr She waits till he's outside. Tries to relax. Then she remembers the book. She takes it in her left hand and tri to open it. It's not easy for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she notices that she's forgotten her glasses. She re the book back on the bed cover and fishes for her glasses the night stand. In the end, she manages it. Then she ope the book again, and tries to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The superintendent's wife puts the filled supermarket bag the counter. Takes the stack of mail that she had put on of one of the bags and puts it down beside them. Then she takes out the receipt and the change. 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately the strawberries were already moldy. I'll go and get you some fresh ones tomorrow from the market. My husband will bring you the bottled water this afternoon. I'm not supposed to carry anything heavy: my back, you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It came to 76 euros and 40 cents. There's the till receipt and here's your change: 23 euros 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. Keep the change. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short embarrassed PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDENT'S WIFE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be off. Call me if you need anything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your wife well? ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she's OK. She's recovering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Give her my regards. My husband and I are very glad she's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we are too. Bye, Mrs. Mry, thanks so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads toward the front door of the apartment, turns around again toward Georges. 23.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERINTENDENT'S WIFE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll bring you the strawberries tomorrow around noon, if that suits you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, she closes the door as she leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands in front of the closed door of the toilet, wait After a while, we hear the noise of flushing. After a whi longer, we hear

dialogues.speaker: ANNE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: There. Can you come in, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the toilet door, goes around Anne, pulls her up, puts her left arm around his neck, keeps herself upright way, he pulls up her pants under her skirt. Then they slo hobble out of the toilet and he sits her back down in the wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both lying in their beds. Anne sleeps, BREATHING NOISILY. Georges lies with his eyes open, listening attentively to her breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun shines in. Georges has cooked something simple. T are both in a good mood, eating and drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... some banal romance or other about a nobleman and a lower middle- class girl who couldn't have each other and who then, out of sheer magnanimity, decide to renounce their love - in fact I don't quite remember it any more. In any case, afterwards I was thoroughly distraught, and it took me a bit of time to calm down. In the courtyard of the house where grandma lived, there was a young guy at the window who asked me where I'd been. He was a couple of years older than me, a braggart who of course really impressed me. "To the movies", I said, because I was proud that my grandma had given me the money to go all alone to the cinema.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "What did you see?" I started to tell him the story of the movie, and as I did, all the emotion came back. I didn't want to cry in front of the boy, but it was impossible; there I was, crying out loud in the courtyard, and I told him the whole drama to the bitter end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? How did he react?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No idea. He probably found it amusing. I don't remember. I don't remember the film either. But I remember the feeling. That I was ashamed of crying, but that telling him the story made all my feelings and tears come back, almost more powerfully than when I was actually watching the film, and that I just couldn't stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, smiles, then turns back to her food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's cute. Why didn't you ever tell me before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are still a few stories you don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha...? Don't tell me you're going to ruin your image in your old age?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet I won't. But what is my image?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a mouthful, eats ponderously. Then she looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes you're a rotter. But you're nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I take you for a drink? 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does physiotherapy exercises with her. Counts the repetitive movements of the exercises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's lying on the sofa. He's seated in the armchair. The both reading the newspaper. After a while:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to this! My horoscope. Motto: You have lots of verve, but need to be more serious! Love: High-class conversation is what you need. Work: You're motivated again. But proceed with care. Health: Loosen up by doing exercises. It'll give you renewed pizzazz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUSE. Then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've only yourself to blame if you read stuff like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief PAUSE. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow afternoon is Pierre's funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fear I must. I don't want to go at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who does like going to funerals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know a few people who do. Annette can never wait to get all dolled up again. And Franois has... 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're mean. What would you say if no one came to your funeral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Nothing, presumably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shoots him a glance, smiles at his irony. Then she sa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you talked to Jeanne since I was in the hospital? I mean, does she know I can't come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit irritated) My God, what are people like when they're shocked? She couldn't believe it, she was speechless. I don't remember any more. In any case, not exactly. I've spoken to a lot of people since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to be unkind, but I just don't see the point of talking about it all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I talk about it all the time? 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door is unlocked from the outside, and Georges enters. He's back from the funeral, dressed for the occas He turns on the light. He's wet. Clearly, it's been raini As he closes the door again, his eyes fall on Anne. With back to him, she is sitting on the floor in front of the opened window of the light well, half propped against her wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ... ?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaken, he heads toward her, picks her up and seats her i the wheelchair. Outside, in the light well, it is raining

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (once she's seated in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you back already? What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges has understood immediately. He closes the window noiselessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then just stands there, at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE. Then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, I was too slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you wheel me into the living room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns toward her, pushes the wheelchair into the livin room between the two armchairs. Turns on the light. Stops beside the switch. They both look exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're always good at surprises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Why are you home earlier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't come home earlier. I took a taxi. In August, there isn't a lot of traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's true. How was the funeral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was it, go on, tell me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks an instant, then goes and sits down facing her an armchair. Looks at her. She raises her head and return his look. He understands that he can't insist right now. PAUSE. Then he begins:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was rather bizarre. The priest was an idiot. Then one of Pierre's co-workers made a speech that was embarrassingly emotional. His old secretary came with a radio- cassette player and after the speech she put on "Yesterday" by the Beatles. You can't imagine. Everybody turned round to look at her. Apparently, it wasn't planned. His grandchildren were there. Of course they giggled as soon as the music began. Then the urn was put on a huge stretcher that was obviously designed for a coffin, and out we went into the rain. They placed the urn on a small electric cart that crawled along for what seemed like an eternity to the tiny hole they had dug. A lot of people had to stifle their laughter. It must have been terrible for Jeanne. I have... 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just no point in going on living. I know it can only get worse. Why should I inflict it on us? On you and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not inflicting anything on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to lie, Georges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine you were me. Didn't you ever think something like this could happen to one of us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I did. But imagination and reality have little in common.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But things are getting better every day. We'll...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges, I don't want to carry on. You're making such efforts to make everything easier for me. But I don't want to go on. For my own sake. Not yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you. I know you. You think you're a burden on me. But what if things were the other way around? What would you do then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I can't be bothered to think about being you. I'm tired. You tire me. Everything tires me. I can't talk. I want to go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her. Finally he gets up and pushes her wheelc out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is lying in bed. The bedside lamp is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the RADIO coming from the living room: a program about the fauna and flora of the South Seas, or something similar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges comes out of the kitchen and opens the front door the doorstep stands the soloist (male or female) from Sce 3 and 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (somewhat perplexed, but pleased) Oh hello! Nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me for dropping in on you like this, Professor. I tried to reach you by phone a couple of times, but no luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I only pick up the phone when I've stored the caller's number and I can see who's calling. Why didn't you leave a message? Anyway, do come in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door behind his guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just couldn't manage to come by after the concert. I was so sorry, because I was so pleased you came along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While they pass into the living room, they continue to sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And now, an unexpected opportunity has arisen because Franois Mitry called me - you know him, he's my agent - to say he'd arranged for me to meet the boss of the Thtre des Champs-Elyses tonight to talk about their new concert series.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I flew to Paris this morning, and while I was in my hotel, I thought, I'll just give it a try and drop in. After all, it's virtually just around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, these are for your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the bouquet of flowers from its wrapping paper a hands it to Georges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, she is. I'll go and get her in a minute. Have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I'm not disturbing you too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not at all. I'm happy that you came. We were so thrilled by your concert. We hoped we'd see you again soon. Please do have a seat. Can I can get you something? A cup of tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, I'll just freshen up the flowers; in this heat they wilt so fast...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've only just bought them. They should keep quite...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Georges has already left the room with the bouquet an closed the door behind him. The soloist looks around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a few moments we hear the VOICES of Anne and George the distance, without understanding what they're saying. lasts a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally Georges opens the door and pushes Anne, in her wheelchair, into the living room. 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin! What a delight. How lovely to see you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The (male or female) soloist has got up and doesn't quite know how to handle the situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Laurent! Lovely to see you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get up. Come on, sit yourself down and don't look so shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soloist sits down hesitantly, Georges pushes the wheelchair between the two armchairs and also sits down. Brief embarrassed PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so proud of you. We were both in raptures after your concert. Georges wanted to buy your new CD the very next morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God! I wanted to bring you the CD, but I left in such a hurry that I forgot it. I'm so sorry. I'll get one today and drop it by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, don't worry. We want to make a contribution to your success. Even if it's only twenty euros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've already contributed so much. I owe you so much, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe it to your hard work and your talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head a little) Do you remember, when you first gave me the Bagatelles to play? I was twelve at the time, and in my youthful arrogance I said: "But why the Bagatelles?" And you really gave me a piece of your mind. 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both smile. PAUSE. Then he goes on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My right side is paralyzed, that's all. It can happen when you get older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk about something else, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be offended. But I want to enjoy the lovely interlude you've given us with your visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't told us yet what's been going on since the Paris concert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soloist is a bit thrown by the couple's behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, actually I've spent most of the time in London studying. Then I went to Copenhagen for two performances, that was Schubert too. My whole life revolves around Schubert at the moment. The concerts with the Impromptus and the Moments Musicaux, and for my bread-and-butter work I'm developing the sonatas. Not the late ones, I think I still need a couple more years for those. 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (The dialogue concerning music will be modified according the performer chosen.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you do me a favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you play Fr Elise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I don't know if I remember it very well. Beethoven, it's been a long time since I've... But if you want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it a try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Georges, then at Anne again, gets up, goes to grand piano and plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is leaning against the chest, and watches Anne, w is practicing maneuvering her new electric wheelchair. Forward, backward, turning. In the end, she goes round an round in circles several times. He laughs, so does she.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is lying in bed. A book rests on her stomach. She listens to the PIANO playing coming from the living room. After a while the music stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is seated in front of the open piano. His hands i his lap, he looks straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The superintendent's wife runs the vacuum cleaner over a carpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is seated on a stool. Georges washes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges has cooked himself a steak and is eating. On the radio, we hear the EVENING NEWS. Suddenly, coming from th neighboring room, a LOUD CRASH and the SOUND of crockery breaking. Stifled CRY from Anne. Georges gets up, irritat crosses the HALLWAY and enters the BEDROOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne lies on the floor, beside the overturned night stand the midst of the crockery and remains of a meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked, and hence furious) Good God, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries toward her and pulls her up rather roughly int the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you lost your senses?! I don't believe it! How stupid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to the broken objects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that! Did you need to do that? Can't you call me when you need something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meekly) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, so am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges bends down, and begins to gather up the scattered objects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lamp is broken too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges, in pajama pants, naked torso, brushes his teeth. doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges spits out, wipes his mouth, goes into the hallway over to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. Georges is very irritated. O.S., Anne calls to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges? What's going on? Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges opens the door. Outside, however, instead of the usual landing, we see an empty room lit a giorno but with a window, about as large as the rooms in the apartment. I looks like an unpainted room in a new apartment. A couple ladders are propped against the opposite wall. At the oth end of the room, to the side, is a small door. Georges is stunned, and doesn't understand what has happened. Hesitating, he crosses the room toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.S., in the distance, Anne's worried voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges? What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges opens the small door. Behind it is a narrow, windowless corridor, as brightly lit as the room. At the of the corridor, a door. Georges heads toward this door a opens it too. Behind it is a tiny windowless room, equall bright as the others. Everything is very quiet. Georges enters, turns round, then goes back along the corridor, crosses the room, comes through the apartment door into t hallway of the apartment. But it too is now empty and bri with bare unpainted walls, no doors; only the door to the bedroom is open. Behind that too, it appears to be empty bright. Georges goes toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the same time, we hear GEORGES' VOICE. At first he gro but then begins inarticulately hollering, louder and loud Shortly after, we also hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges, what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. GEORGES HOLLERS 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down will you! There's nothing there. It's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She manages to switch on the bedside lamp. Georges is sit up in his bed, having just awoken, wide-eyed with terror. breathing is labored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne extends her good hand toward him, caresses his back calm him. He slowly calms down and flops back on his pill

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't answer. Continues breathing heavily. She cares him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still with labored breathing) I didn't understand... I thought I'd gone mad... It was something impossible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close shot on the screen of a cell phone. We read on it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming to Paris on 12th. Plan to stop by in afternoon. Ho all well. So look forward to seeing you. Love Eva.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear O.S. the voice of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva. They're coming on the 12th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crouches down in front of Anne who is seated on the be puts his mobile phone back in his pocket and continues to on her socks and her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No idea. Apparently she's coming with Geoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When is it? 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know exactly. What day is it today? I'll go and look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff doesn't need to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges doesn't agree, but continues to dress Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need any comments on my predicament. I can only take his British humor in small doses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once more the set of physiotherapy exercises. Things are going better. Georges smiles encouragingly at Anne, notic her improvement. She reacts like someone duty-bound, but without conviction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close shot: a CD is inserted into a player. As the MUSIC begins (the concert heard in Scene 3), Georges takes a ca out of the envelope that contained the CD and reads it to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Madame Laurent, Dear Monsieur Laurent, it was beautiful and yet sad to see you. My heartfelt wishes that things will get better. With deep gratitude, your former pupil, Martin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MUSIC makes their SILENCE less awkward. Then, after a long while, Anne says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop the CD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hesitates, looks at her, then stops the music. They re SILENT. 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They eat. Suddenly, Anne says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are the family albums?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family albums? I don't know, there, in the other room. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you get them for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Anne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to look at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges hesitates, and doesn't understand the suddenness this request.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finally gets up and goes into the adjoining room. He c back after a few moments with a stack of albums, pushes a the remains of Anne's meal and sets down the first album front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit irritated) You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With her able hand, Anne opens the album, looks at the photos, turns the pages, looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (self-consciously, softly) What? 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life...so long... What a long life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges looks at her. She continues to thumb through the pages. After a while she turns toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop watching me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caught in the act) I wasn't watching you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you were. I'm not that dumb yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both lying in bed. Georges reads the day's news Anne from the newspaper. When he looks over to her, she h fallen asleep. He then puts the newspaper on the night st and turns out the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's morning. Georges is helping Anne to get out of bed i her wheelchair. As he does it, he notices that the bed an her nightgown are wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're soaked through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits her back on the bed and goes out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this time, she remains seated, feeling embarrassed and waits. He comes back with a towel and puts it on the of the wheelchair. 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no big deal. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts her out of the bed into the wheelchair and pushe her through the hallway into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts her out of the wheelchair, sits her on the stool takes off her wet nightgown, pulling it over her head. Sh starts to SOB inconsolably. He caresses her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, darling. It's nothing serious. Things like that happen..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't... take it any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds her tightly against him, strokes her hair, feeli helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My love. My darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is in bed. She's on a drip. Eva is seated on a chair beside the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... thinking about whether it wouldn't be better to invest the money in an apartment block. If inflation gets going again, property is the only sure thing. Right now, savings accounts pay 1.75% at best. Four years ago, Geoff bought some stocks with a small sum of money and the whole thing collapsed. So now we're obviously worried. Unfortunately, in the meantime, other people have had the same idea, and property prices are going through the roof. Since we came back from Scandinavia, I spend all my spare time looking through newspaper ads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To put an end to the PAUSE that follows, she adds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes time, that's all. We'll find something in the end. 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another oppressive PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) Yes yes I have... I have... the grandmother... woman with house... not... the house then ... money

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand you, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... yes... now... it's all... house sel... sel... sel... was... in two strokes of... so quickly... god it's hard... to say... sell... money gone... left... there too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUSE. Eva has tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges and Eva's husband, GEOFF, around fifty. He speaks with a British accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... three times a week... I'm not experienced enough. We'll see if that's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much is she asking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's paid by the hour. We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff nods. Georges shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to say. Sometimes I get the feeling she's totally unaware of the state she's in. And then I feel the opposite. It's... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about the doctor? What does he say? 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva comes in through the door. She's in floods of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She only talks gibberish. I don't know what...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff gets up, hesitantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, dear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes toward her and leads her to the armchair where he sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...come here, sit down, it's OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes him off, irritated, and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing is OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first he's vexed by her brusque response, but then goe sit down on the sofa. Meanwhile, Eva turns to Georges:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on, actually? You can't just leave her lying on her bed like that! She's unrecognizable! It's ridiculous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't do anything for the moment. Calm down, darling. She's getting medical treatment, they give her the necessary medication, and there are no other options right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean, "no other options"? Why isn't she in a hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had a second stroke. Bertier examined her and felt we could spare her all the hospital inpatient procedures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, they wouldn't keep her, they'd send her to a care home. What they do in those places, we can do here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva looks at him, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she won't be put in a care home. I promised her that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think you're taking on too much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a better idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Geoff doesn't know what to say. Eva has composed herself somewhat and blows her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe that these days there's no way of handling this efficiently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's stopping you from finding out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva gets up, furious, and goes to the window. Georges fol her with his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I love your mother as much as you do. So please, don't treat me as if I was a total idiot incapable of doing the obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. I'm simply questioning whether what I see going on here is the answer to everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to get a second opinion? 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you two had better stop, OK? Another doctor did come. He said Bertier was right. From Monday, a nurse will come three times a week. Now can we talk about something else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges washes the tea cups that he used for Eva and Geof On the radio, the EVENING NEWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With expert gestures, a nurse shows Georges how to lie An down and put an incontinence pad on her. She's now almost incapable of moving, and has to be turned over like an object, as tears flow silently down her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is at the piano and plays the piece from the Scene 3 watch her and listen to her for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is seated in his armchair and looks at the piano. Finally he leans over toward the CD player and stops it. MUSIC suddenly stops. Georges remains silently seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He prepares a bowl of muesli, fills a sipping cup with wa and brings both into the bedroom. Sits down on the bed cl to Anne to feed her her food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, my love, I hope you like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to feed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I added a little orange juice. I find it tastes quite good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can only swallow slowly, and so something keeps runni back out of her mouth. He wipes it with a tea towel, continues to feed her. Finally, after a few mouthfuls, sh keeps her mouth shut. 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Anne, you have to eat some more. You've only swallowed three mouthfuls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne continues to keep her lips sealed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, darling. A bit more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne doesn't move. He puts the muesli on the night stand holds the sipping cup to her lips. She drinks slowly, one after the other. He pulls the cup back between each sip, give her more time. Suddenly she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mom to the concert...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mom to the concert... no dress...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom has no dress for the concert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mom to concert... no ... uuu... no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long PAUSE. Georges waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges and the nurse install Anne on a metal armchair in shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she does so, the nurse keeps talking reassuringly to A Finally, she turns on the tap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a monotone) Help! Help! Help! Help! Help! Help!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without being phased, the nurse continues to speak reassuringly. Georges remains standing there, helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges and the nurse are seated at the table with a cup coffee. In front of the nurse, on the table, is a sum of money. As they speak, we hear, coming from the room, Anne CALLS FOR HELP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... we could take turns. She'd come from 8 till 12 and I'd do 2 until 6, or 3 to 7. That would certainly relieve the pressure on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just has to know in time so she can arrange it in her schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, I'll let you know in the next few days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. I have to go now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the money on the table, pockets it and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure. I'll see you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both leave the kitchen. As the nurse, in the hallway takes her jacket off the hook in the closet and puts it o she comments on Anne's continuing CALLS FOR HELP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mustn't take it too seriously. Usually they always say something. She might just as well say "Mom, Mom, Mom". It's just mechanical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding, softly) I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've reached the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, sir. 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door behind her. Remains motionless a momen then goes into the bedroom, where Anne's CALLS FOR HELP, unaltered, continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges sits down beside Anne on the bed, takes her hand, holds her. After a while, Anne calms down, her CALLS FOR become quieter and finally stop altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a long PAUSE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly, softly) I'd like to hire a second nurse. The two could take turns. That would make everything a bit simpler. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long PAUSE. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) ...Help...Help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both lying in bed. Georges SNORES noisily. Anne' eyes are open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door. We hear the key in the lock. Georges ente with a shopping bag, and behind him is the superintendent carries bigger and heavier bags. Georges holds the door o for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind putting them in the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The superintendent precedes him into the kitchen with the bags. Georges calls toward the bedroom:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ba-aack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He then follows the superintendent into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The superintendent has put the bags on the work surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks very much. 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I do anything else for you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks, Mr. Mry. You've been a big help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's nothing, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges has already taken out his wallet and gives some m to the superintendent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks a lot, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll let you know if I need you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With pleasure, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets ready to leave. He stops again in the doorway and turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I say something, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife and I, we're very impressed by the way you're managing everything. I take my hat off to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks, Georges' mobile phone has started to ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the mobile phone from the pocket of his jacket) That's very kind of you. Thanks. See you soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give my regards to your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I certainly will. Thanks. 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the superintendent leaves the apartment, Georges looks the display on his mobile phone and makes a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Eva, how are you?... Things are fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges, standing at the foot of the bed, faces Anne and starts singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insistently)...Sur le pont ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Ssssur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sur le pont...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: po ... pont ... sss

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Sur le pont ... Sur le pont ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Ssssur le pont ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling to encourage her): ... Sur le pont d'Avignon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... ssur... le ..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... pont... Sur le pont d'Avignon... (he begins to sing): Sur le pont d'Avignon on y danse, on y danse, sur le pont d'Avignon tout le monde y danse en rond...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He encourages her to sing with him. Starts singing again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sur le pont d' Avignon, on y danse, on y danse ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne tries to sing too, she has a hint of a smile on her face, but she produces only isolated SOUNDS. 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing to encourage Anne, accompanied by the sounds that she produces): Sur le pont d'Avignon on y danse, on y danse ... Sur le pont d'Avignon tout le monde y danse en rond ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second nurse is doing Anne's hair roughly. The brush st in her tangled hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... there we are...now we're all beautiful again...so everybody will admire us...there...you see... wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes a mirror that she has placed within reach. Hold in front of Anne's face.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well?... What do we say to that? Aren't we a pretty sight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne, sickened, averts her eyes. Emits a muffled SOUND. T nurse ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll see, Monsieur will be dazzled by you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Furious SOUND from Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The window opening onto the light well is open. A pigeon landed on the window ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It walks to and fro, then finally dares to jump down insi onto the floor. It starts to explore the surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the TOILET FLUSH. Georges comes out of the toilet The door opening frightens the pigeon. Alarmed, flapping wings, it flutters about the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment of surprise, Georges tries to shoo it back toward the window. But the bird escapes in the opposite direction. George follows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the doors of the other rooms. Coming from the bedroom, we faintly hear ANNE'S VOICE. 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges fetches a towel from the bathroom. He chases the bird. He hits out at the bird for so long that it escapes back out through the window. Georges, visibly exhausted, to sit down on the chest in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges and the second nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... as you wish, sir. I don't know what you were expecting. I gave up another job to come and work here. You should have thought it over before deciding whether you wanted a second nurse or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've only just found out how incompetent you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to discuss it with you. Anyway, you wouldn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one has ever complained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you. (To get rid of her) How much do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a brief calculation) Seven hundred and eighty euros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges takes his wallet from his jacket hanging on the armchair and takes out eight one-hundred euro bills. The nurse is hopping mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
