dialogues.text: I've never had anything like this happen to me before. Who do you think you are?! I've been doing this job for ten years. I don't need you to teach me how to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have twenty euros? 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse takes out her purse angrily, looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then take the eight hundred euros. You can go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse pockets the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a nasty old man. I feel sorry for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges has put back his wallet, turns to her again and l at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope from the bottom of my heart that one day someone treats you the way you treat your patients, and that you too will have no way of defending yourself. Now get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, at first doesn't know what to answer, t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go fuck yourself, you old fart!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves, slamming the door behind her. A few seconds later, we hear the front door of the apartment fall shut. Georges sits down in his armchair, looks straight ahead. he lights a cigarette, his hands shake, he smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries to pour some tea into her mouth with the sipping cup. She won't loosen her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Please, open your mouth... go on... open it... Anne! Please!... come on... stop that!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits upright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't drink, you'll die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indecipherable SOUND from ANNE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what you want? 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUSE. She looks at him. He bends over her again, present the cup in front of her sealed lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Anne, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't react. He opens her lips with his fingers and tries carefully, but using some force, to separate her te Pours a little tea in. The liquid runs out of her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddammit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts down the cup, takes a towel and wipes the liquid, some of which has run down onto the pillow. He tries to m it up. She watches him the whole time. Finally he puts th towel down beside the cup and looks at her. Tries not to his helplessness and his anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne! ... You can't force me to let you die of thirst. If you persist, I'll call Bertier and he'll put you in hospital. They can force-feed you there. Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised to spare you that. But you must help me. I'm out of my depth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the cup again and puts it against her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Anne!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her lips remain sealed. He presses the cup hard against t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink that, now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hurts her, so she opens her mouth and lets in a little liquid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes her mouth again and he puts down the cup. 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she spits it all out like a fountain. After a moment bewilderment, he slaps her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE. He's frightened by his own gesture. Then he puts down the cup and sits on the chair beside the bed. They d look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help... help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Help... Help... Help... Help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The various paintings hanging in the apartment. Without t frames. Like views on various realities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE. Sometimes, the REMOTE sound of TRAFFIC in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is drinking tea and reading the newspaper. SILENC Suddenly, the DOORBELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges, annoyed, puts down his newspaper, gets up, goes the hallway and goes to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me. 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit irritated) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges, panicked, thinks for a few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes toward the bedroom door, locks it and puts the ke his pocket. He goes into the dining room, also closes the door leading to the bedroom. He comes back. He is about t toward the front door, but remains motionless an instant, opens the door of the toilet that is located just nearby, flushes the toilet, closes the toilet door again and open the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brief kiss hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. What was going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in the toilet. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the front door behind Eva, indicates the direct of the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva points to the bedroom with a questioning look. He sha his head as if to play down the question, and indicates b in the direction of the living room, as if to say: "You understand, huh?". Eva is slightly irritated, but follows into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why this unannounced visit? Where have you come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on with Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. What should be going on? 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... (gesture toward the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to sit down first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva wants to answer, but finally gives in and sits down. Georges does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why are you in Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on with Mom? Why don't you answer the phone? After our last conversation, I left four messages on your answering machine. Why don't you call back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I didn't listen to it. Forgive me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you realize we're worried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your worries are no use to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, don't get me wrong. I'm not criticizing you. I just don't have the time to deal with your worries, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Let's stop this conversation right there. I'm taking care of your mother. It's a full-time job. And I'm not saying that to complain, just to explain why I didn't answer your phone calls and why I don't want to have any pointless discussions on the subject. Your mother is just as could have been expected: bad the whole time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is turning more and more into a helpless child, and it's sad and humiliating, for her and for me. And she doesn't want to be seen in that state either. Even the last time you visited, she didn't want you to come. You two have your own life. Nothing wrong with that. But let us have our life too. Even though it's a lousy one. OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's the matter; your visit caught me by surprise. And I'm annoyed that you show up here to check that everything's OK. Who do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUSE. Eva is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she gets up and makes to go to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here, will you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops short, looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, but insistently) Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates a moment, but winds up leaving the living r

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom? ... Mom??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges remains seated, motionless, until she comes back. seems upset by the situation, as one would expect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, what's going on? Have you gone crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sit down. 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to sit down. What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's going on. I want to spare us all a pointless drama. I presume your mother is asleep. She mostly sleeps the whole day. And then she wakes up at night. If you really want to, we'll go and see her in a little while. Now, sit down. OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly, Eva heads toward her armchair and sits down. PAUSE. Then Georges goes on in a quiet voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do our speech exercises every day, or we sing together. Most of the time, I wake up around 5. At that time, she's still awake. Then we change her incontinence pad. I rub cream on her to avoid sores. Then, around 7, I try to persuade her to eat and drink. Sometimes it works, sometimes not. Sometimes she tells me things from her childhood, then for hours she calls for help, and then an instant later she's giggling away to herself, or crying. Nothing of any of that is worth showing to anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE. Eva looks down. Finally, she says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't stop me from seeing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They remain seated for a moment, finally Eva gets up. Geo follows her into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He unlocks the door and they enter the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bright light from outside filters through the blinds. 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva goes over to the bed, looks at Anne. Finally, she caresses her face, shyly and clumsily. Anne opens her eye Looks at her. No movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne emits a FURIOUS SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I do something for you? Mom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom... Mom... Mom... Mom... Mom...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges has remained by the door. After a while, they bot leave the bedroom, cross the hallway to come back in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges closes the door. For an instant he puts a consoli hand on Eva's shoulder. Then he sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva, trying to compose herself, goes toward the window an looks outside. Suddenly she starts sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a while, Georges gets up and goes out of the room. vexed, blows her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shortly after, Georges comes back. He has another teacup his hand, puts it down beside his on the table and sits d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tea isn't very hot any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva turns toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it does make you feel better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a short PAUSE, Eva comes toward the table. Sits dow He fills her cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the cup, drinks. Replaces it. Still can't bring herself to look at him. 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was silly of me to lock the door. I'm sorry. You took me by surprise, that's all. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods her head, indicating she understands. Finally sh looks at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going to happen now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a little ironic laugh) What's going to happen now? The nurse comes twice a week, and every two weeks Dr. Bertier and the hairdresser come. That's what you want to know, right? Things will go on as they have done up until now. They'll go from bad to worse. Things will go on, and then one day it will all be over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief PAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't go on like this, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't I? What do you suggest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we have a serious talk, you and me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you call "a serious talk"? What do you want to suggest? Do you want to have Mom live with you? Do you want to pack her off to a care home? Do you? What do you want? Go on, talk to me "seriously"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eva looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is seated on the bed beside Anne, who is still bedridden. 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a rush)... short... short dress... only I... only I... all long... it was... (with a small gesture to imitate a bell): ding... dong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it swung to and fro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still rushed) ... yes... to ... fro ... you... very serious... like that... (she imitates a serious countenance, continues in a low voice): like that... serious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unable to keep from laughing a little) Yes. I think I was pretty uptight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) yes... up... tight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUSE. Anne puts her hand on Georges'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... it was n...nice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is shaving. Suddenly we hear, coming from the bedroom,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud) Help... Help... Help... Help... Help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges wipes his face and, to the sound of Anne's cries, crosses the hallway and enters the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne continues to cry out in a monotone to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges goes over to her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to calm her like a sick child) What is it?..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in pain?... What's the matter?... Is your pad full?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises her blanket for an instant and sniffs, then replaces it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... So what's hurting you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down beside her on the bed. Takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right... it's all right ... I'm here... everything's fine... we'll... Hold on, I'll tell you a story... but you must be quiet, I can't talk too loud, it wears me out... Here we go: when I was little... well, I wasn't as little as all that... it was toward the end of primary school, so I was about ten, Dad and Mom sent me to a holiday camp. They thought it would do me good to spend the summer with kids my own age... We were lodged in an old castle in the midst of a magnificent wooded landscape... I think it was in the Auvergne... I don't know... in any case it was the opposite of what I'd expected... We had to get up at 6 and go for a morning swim. Not far from the castle, there was a pond fed by an icy mountain stream. We entered it running, in a double file. You know, I was never very sporty. They had a program to keep us on the go all day, probably to nip any potential pubescent impulses in the bud ... But the worst thing was the food. The third day after our arrival, there was rice pudding for lunch. I hate rice pudding. We sat at long tables in a huge hall. I didn't want to eat the stuff and the housemaster said to me: You won't get up until you've cleared your plate. So after the meal everybody left the room, and I remained seated, in tears. I had made a secret pact with Mom. I was to send her a postcard every week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was pleased with the place I was to draw some flowers on it, or if not, some stars. She kept the card; it was covered all over in stars. After three hours, I was allowed to leave the table. I went up to my room, got into bed and had a fever of 42 degrees. It was diphtheria. They took me to the nearest hospital where I was put in an isolation ward, which meant that Mom, when she came to visit me, could only wave at me through a window. At some point I lost that postcard. It's a pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne has become ever calmer during Georges' story. He sti holds her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Georges reaches across Anne's body to get hold of hi pillow and presses it over her face. STIFLED SOUNDS from Anne. Everything that can still move in her body starts t move. Georges presses down heavily on the pillow, lies on with his whole weight, for a long time, until all Anne's movements stop. Then he sits up, exhausted, and without removing the pillow from her face, remains seated beside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door of the apartment is unlocked. Georges, in clothes, enters with two big shopping bags full of cut flowers. He puts down the bags, takes off his coat, hangs in the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TELEPHONE RINGS. Georges takes the bags and carries t in the kitchen, puts them in the sink, fills it with wate He starts to cut the stems and put the flowers in the wat We watch him doing so for a while. Meanwhile, the TELEPHO HAS STOPPED RINGING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges has opened one of the sections of the large wall closet. He is looking for a specific dress. He takes some out, puts them back inside. One of the dresses slips off hanger and falls to the floor. He picks it up, hangs it u again. He ends up finding the one he was looking for. He takes it out on its hanger. Closes the closet again. 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks at the dress. Then he lowers his arm a little and i about to leave the bedroom. He catches his feet in the dr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just saves himself from tripping up by grabbing on to wheelchair that is parked there. Exhausted, he flops down into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With wide adhesive tape, Georges seals up the door frame the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is seated at the kitchen table where he had break with Anne in Scene 8, and writes a letter. PAUSES for reflection. GENTLE COOING OF PIGEONS, scarcely audible. Suddenly, Georges starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the far end of the long kitchen, beside the door betwe the kitchen units, a pigeon is walking. Georges stares at For a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he gets up slowly and, via the door located beside t kitchen table, he goes into the adjoining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the sofa there, he has set up his new bed. He takes th wool blanket from the bed and comes back into the kitchen carefully approaches the pigeon that then runs off in ala Georges carefully opens up the blanket and finally throws over the pigeon. But it manages to escape into the hallwa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges follows it. This action is repeated several times The pigeon is more and more panicky, starts to fly up, flutters about in all directions. Georges closes the ligh well window to cut off its escape route. This lasts an exhausting amount of time, but he ends up capturing it. H cuddles it against him, rolled up in the blanket, leans against a wall, then holds it as if it were a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the adjoining room, we see Georges seated at the kit table, writing. Finally we see what he is writing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... you won't believe it. A pigeon came in, for the secon time already, through the light well. This time I caught In fact it wasn't difficult at all. But I set it free aga I'm going to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges is lying on his bed in the adjoining room, starin the ceiling. O.S., we faintly hear the SOUND of running water, and from time to time the CLATTERING OF DISHES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a while, Georges gets up and goes into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He remains in the doorway and watches Anne who, doing the dishes, at first doesn't pay attention to him, then notic his presence and shoots him a quick glance, saying casual

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm almost done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges continues to look at her unwaveringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can put your shoes on if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges looks at her an instant longer, passes beside her goes into the hallway, sits down on a stool beside the cl and puts on his shoes. O.S. we hear Anne finishing her wo She comes out, hangs up her apron in the closet, disappea for a few moments into the bathroom. Meanwhile, Georges h got up, and looks in the bathroom where, clearly, Anne is tidying her hair and sprucing herself up. When she comes again, he takes her coat from the closet and helps her pu on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head for the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you taking a coat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georges thinks a few seconds, then takes his trench-coat the hook and they leave the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four long shots: all the windows are open. The sun is shining. It is fairly bright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENCE. Then the SOUND OF A LOCK BEING OPENED. Eva comes into the apartment. Remains a long time beside the door. Looks around her, ill at ease. Finally she hesitantly goe into the bedroom. 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne's twin bed isn't there any more. On Georges' bed lie only the bare mattress. Eva remains there a moment, then through the partition door into the dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, everything is as usual. Eva continues into the liv room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There too, everything is as usual. Eva stops by the piano stool. Looks out of the window, feeling at a loss. Then s heads toward the sofa and armchairs in the corner. On the table lie the remains of a snack. Eva looks at the table, turns again toward the open windows, through which we hea STREET NOISE. Then she sits down, exhausted, in one of th armchairs. Her diminutive frame seems lost in the big roo
